title: Barr Says Democrats Are Trying to Weaken Presidential Power
summary: In speech to conservatives, attorney general decries demands for documents and testimony. WASHINGTON-Congressional Democrats are flooding the White House and other agencies with demands for documents and testimony to erode executive power permanently and undermine President Trump, Attorney General William Barr said Friday.

title: Little-Known Bolivian Politician Leads Turbulent Nation in Transition
summary: Suddenly thrust into the presidency with Evo Morales's departure, Jeanine Añez pledges new elections soon. LA PAZ, Bolivia-Jeanine Añez was the senate vice president and little-known even in her native Bolivia before longtime President Evo Morales resigned this week along with his vice president and the two heads of congress.

title: Trump Intervenes in War Crimes Cases Against Three U.S. Military Members
summary: President issues pardons for two and orders the restoration of rank for a third member despite Pentagon concerns. President Trump intervened in war crime cases against three members of the U.S. military on Friday, issuing pardons for two and restoring the rank of a third, all despite Pentagon concerns that such actions could undermine the military justice system.

title: Charges for Jeffrey Epstein's Jail Guards Coming as Soon as Next Week
summary: Corrections officers have rejected a plea deal from federal prosecutors. A pair of correctional officers who were guarding Jeffrey Epstein's unit the night he died rejected federal prosecutors' offer of a plea deal and could be charged in connection with the disgraced financier's suicide as early as next week, people familiar with the matter said Friday.

title: Impeachment Hearings: Marie Yovanovitch Says She Felt Threatened by Trump
summary: Former Ukraine envoy cited president's comments in call with Ukrainian counterpart. WASHINGTON-The former ambassador to Ukraine, who was fired this spring, felt threatened by disparaging comments from President Trump and was alarmed by the State Department's failure to defend her, she testified in the second public impeachment hearing.

title: Ford Workers Agree to New Labor Deal
summary: Ratification gives UAW leaders momentum as they try to complete contract talks, turning to Fiat Chrysler next. The United Auto Workers union said Friday it has secured a new labor deal at Ford Motor Co. , after unionized workers at the company's U.S. factories voted to back the agreement.

title: In California School Shooting, Investigation Turns to Motive
summary: Detectives worked through night collecting evidence in Saugus High School shooting that left two students dead. Law-enforcement officials continued to search for a motive in the deadly school shooting in Santa Clarita, Calif., that left two students dead and three injured.

title: First Trump-Zelensky Call Shows None of the Pressure of the Second
summary: Rough transcript released by the White House displays mostly pleasantries. WASHINGTON-A rough transcript of President Trump's first phone call with Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky, released by the White House on Friday, shows mostly pleasantries between the two leaders whose communications are a central piece of evidence in the House impeachment inquiry.

title: SEC Whistleblower Tips Decline as Agency Looks to Limit Big Awards
summary: Tips to the U.S. securities regulator about corporate wrongdoing declined in fiscal 2019 for the first time since the program was established. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission reported its first annual decline in tips from corporate whistleblowers as the agency prepares to finalize a proposal that could limit the size of big awards.

title: Five Moments That Mattered in Yovanovitch's Testimony
summary: Hearing was marked by former Ukraine envoy's emotional response to attacks against her, GOP's defense of president's authority. Testimony on Friday from Marie Yovanovitch, the former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine, refocused attention in the impeachment inquiry on Rudy Giuliani's fusillade of attacks against her that purportedly fueled President Trump's decision to recall her from her diplomatic post.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Google Appeal of Oracle Win in Copyright Case
summary: Justices will examine protections for computer code, fair use by other programmers. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court agreed to hear an appeal by Alphabet Inc . 's Google, challenging its loss to Oracle Corp. in a copyright case that could produce a multibillion-dollar verdict and have wide ramifications for the software industry.

title: Adam Schiff, Founding Father
summary: The chief impeacher tries to redefine 'bribery' under the law.. Democratic Rep. Adam Schiff isn't a constitutional scholar, but he plays one on Impeachment TV. His latest gambit is an attempt to redefine "bribery" in the Constitution to include President Trump's behavior toward Ukraine.

title: Elizabeth Warren Loves 'Billionaire Tears'
summary: She's naming and shaming rich citizens, even if they're liberals.. Elizabeth Warren, during the Democratic debate last month, said she was "really shocked at the notion that anyone thinks I'm punitive. Look, I don't have a beef with billionaires." This week Ms. Warren's campaign began selling a $25 coffee mug emblazoned with the words: "Billionaire Tears."

title: Bankers Aren't Climate Scientists
summary: Powell says the Fed's mandate doesn't include reducing CO2 emissions.. Liberals criticize President Trump for politicizing the Federal Reserve, and not without cause, but then they demand that the central bank exercise its vast powers against climate change. Credit to Fed Chairman Jay Powell for telling Congress that climate stability isn't part of its mandate.

title: North Carolina GOP Lawmakers Redraw State's Congressional Map
summary: New lines in response to court ruling endanger two GOP seats, but Democrats plan suit, saying districts still aren't fair. RALEIGH, N.C.-A replacement map for North Carolina's congressional districts was finalized Friday, with its lines redrawn to address alleged extreme partisan bias and endangering re-election prospects for two Republicans next year.

title: Netflix, T-Mobile, Alphabet: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: While the Dow hit records this past week, here are seven stocks that moved on news. Netflix Inc.

title: Centrifugal Forces Tug at the World
summary: Spain's former leader, José María Aznar, reflects on secession movements at home and in Europe, and on the Trump era's challenges to the postwar order.. Miami

title: China and the Swamp Are 5G Allies
summary: Shades of Tom Wheeler as the FCC buckles to a Trump agenda instead of freeing up spectrum.. The swamp has lately gained a face-that of Louisiana Republican Sen. John Kennedy. The guide who would lead us out of the swamp and into the broad, sunlit uplands of 5G freedom also has a face-that of Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai.

title: Beware Warren's 'Madisonian' Plan for Public Education
summary: Many of her ideas have already been tried in Wisconsin's capital city, where schools are in crisis.. The unofficial theme of Elizabeth Warren's presidential campaign is that the Massachusetts senator has a plan for everything. Last month Ms. Warren's campaign revealed the details of her plan for K-12 education, which would increase federal funding for public schools by $800 billion over 10 years, strengthen teachers unions, and halt the growth of public charter schools.

title: Two Encounters With Reformed Radical Peter Collier
summary: He exposed CIA funding of a magazine in the '60s and ran a book publisher of the same name in the '90s.. I cannot fix the date or place of my first meeting with Peter Collier, who died at 80 on Nov. 1. It must have been some time in the late 1980s, after he and David Horowitz had their "second thoughts" about their youthful radicalism and published their notorious manifesto, "Lefties for Reagan," in the Washington Post. The two were transformed overnight into personae non gratae, enemies of the movement.

title: Notable & Quotable: Kethledge on Activism
summary: 'The judge's interpretation of a law is therefore both impartial and relatively predictable. But an agency's often is neither.'. Judge Raymond Kethledge of the Sixth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, delivering the annual Hayek Lecture to New York University's Classical Liberal Institute, Nov. 7:

title: Warren Gives Timeline for Move to 'Medicare for All' System
summary: As president, Democrat would push transition period early, then vows full legislation in her third year. Sen. Elizabeth Warren proposed a transition period for moving the nation to a Medicare for All health system and said that if she were elected president, legislation would be passed by the Democrat's third year in office.

title: Dispute Between Taylor Swift, Former Label Flares Again
summary: Barbs are traded over pop star's right to perform her old hits. Taylor Swift and her former label traded barbs in an escalating dispute over the pop star's right to perform her old hits.

title: Obama Appointee Denied Long Tenure as Trump Ambassador
summary: Another impeachment hearing shows why voters should decide when the Trump presidency ends.. Nobody enjoys getting fired. And getting fired by Donald Trump can be particularly unpleasant. But as involuntary separations go, an Obama ambassador being reassigned to another job within the Trump State Department while picking up a Georgetown fellowship is not the hardest of landings.

title: Texas Appeals Court Blocks Inmate's Execution
summary: Rodney Reed was set for lethal injection for the 1996 killing of 19-year-old Stacey Stites. HOUSTON-Texas' top appeals court on Friday halted the scheduled execution of inmate Rodney Reed, whose conviction is being questioned by new evidence that his supporters say raises serious doubt about his guilt.

title: TikTok Wades Into Online Shopping
summary: Popular video-sharing app lets some users add links to shopping sites. TikTok is testing a new feature that could give the popular video-sharing app an entry into e-commerce and a new way to make money beyond advertising to its growing U.S. audience.

title: 'Volume Control' Review: Hear Ye! Hear Ye!
summary: A primer on sound and hearing, full of advice for people of any age to consider if they want to preserve their ability to listen to music, carry on conversations, be capable of accurately detecting sarcasm or listen to the presidential debates.. Getting older-everyone's favorite alternative to dying-inevitably means a loss of hearing. Even if that seems far away in your own future, it's likely you at least interact with someone in your life who is suffering hearing loss right now-parent, grandparent, spouse. According to the World Health Organization, within 30 years there will be nearly 1 billion people with hearing loss. And today, for the first time, there are more people in the world over 65 than under 5. You may have heard that children are our future. They're not. Old people are. Lots of them.

title: 'Family Papers' Review: Diaspora and Destiny
summary: Through the experiences of a single family, a historian traces a once-flourishing community of Sephardic Jews from the Ottoman Empire to the present.. Like Jerusalem, the northern Greek port city of Salonica on the Aegean Sea-or Thessaloniki, as it is more often known today-has for most of its long history been governed from elsewhere: from the 15th to the 20th centuries, by Constantinople (or Istanbul); after 1912, by Athens; and during World War II, by Berlin. Throughout, its often sizable Jewish community has been caught in the city's political storms and buffeted by its shifts of fortune.

title: 'The History of Philosophy' Review: Thinking Through the Ages
summary: Philosophy's questions seem timeless, but its methods are not. The Greeks were the ﬁrst to use reason systematically.. Philosophy is a uniquely reflexive activity. It tends to swallow any question about itself and make it into just more philosophy. Other disciplines are different. The history of physics is not physics. You cannot win a Nobel Prize in chemistry by determining who the first chemist was. And book reviews rarely rise to the level of literature.

title: Three Convicted of Manslaughter in New York City Explosion
summary: The 2015 explosion killed two people and injured more than a dozen. A building owner, plumber and contractor were convicted of manslaughter Friday for causing a 2015 explosion in Manhattan's East Village that killed two men and injured more than a dozen people.

title: NRA Paid LaPierre $2.2 Million in 2018, a 55% Increase
summary: National Rifle Association filings detail CEO's compensation, also show that former President Oliver North was paid $1.38 million for a TV contract. National Rifle Association CEO Wayne LaPierre's compensation rose 55% in 2018, to $2.2 million, and former NRA President Oliver North received $1.38 million as part of a since-disputed contract to host an NRA TV show.

title: U.S. Retail Sales Rebounded in October
summary: Spending at gas stations was up 1.1%, helping drive overall advance in sales. WASHINGTON-Americans spent more on shopping in October while pulling back on nonessential items, suggesting consumers' willingness to buy remained solid but more cautious.

title: Dow Jones Industrial Average Tops 28000
summary: Optimism over the economy from the Fed chairman lifts markets as S&P 500, Nasdaq also hit records. The Dow Jones Industrial Average crossed 28000 for the first time Friday, notching a new record as fading recession fears extended the decadelong bull-market rally.

title: House Ethics Committee Extends Probes of Tlaib and Huizenga
summary: Panel also begins investigating Rep. Hastings's relationship with staffer. WASHINGTON-The House Ethics Committee is continuing its investigations into two members for possible campaign finance violations while announcing the existence of another probe into a member's relationship with a staffer.

title: Caesars-Eldorado Casino Merger Gets Shareholder Approval
summary: The $8.58 billion cash-and-stock deal creates the largest casino operator in the U.S.. Shareholders of Eldorado Resorts Inc. and Caesars Entertainment Corp. approved an $8.58 billion cash-and-stock merger that would create the largest casino operator in the U.S.

title: Apple Powers Dow to 28000
summary: Maker of iPhone accounted for 434 points of blue-chip gauge's 1,000-point climb. Gains in shares of everything from banks to manufacturers helped propel the Dow Jones Industrial Average to 28000 for the first time ever Friday. But one stock powered the index's latest 1,000-point rally: Apple.

title: Steve Wynn Challenges Nevada Gambling Regulators' Authority to Punish Him
summary: A fine, the filing said, would amount to an exorbitant 'exit tax' to leave Nevada's gaming industry. Steve Wynn can't be punished with fines by Nevada gambling regulators, the former Las Vegas magnate's attorneys argued in a filing this week, because he has already left the casino industry and remains willing to stay out.

title: U.S. Presses South Korea to Pay More for Military Alliance
summary: Defense Secretary Mark Esper visits Seoul ahead of current agreement's expiration date; pushback on amount sought. SEOUL-U.S. Defense Secretary Mark Esper reiterated Washington's position that Seoul pay more for American military support on the Korean Peninsula, as South Korea is wealthy enough to shoulder a larger portion of the cost.

title: Stone Found Guilty of Lying to Congress, Witness Tampering
summary: Trial focused on role of GOP operative as conduit between the Trump 2016 campaign and the organization WikiLeaks. WASHINGTON-Roger Stone, a flamboyant Republican operative and longtime adviser to President Trump, was found guilty Friday of lying to Congress and witness tampering, making him the latest member of the president's circle to be convicted on federal charges.

title: Johnson & Johnson's Oklahoma Opioid Penalty Reduced to $465 Million
summary: Judge's order comes as state attorneys general work on finalizing a broad opioid settlement to resolve thousands of cases. An Oklahoma judge reduced a verdict against Johnson & Johnson by more than $100 million in a closely watched opioid case, an expected move that fell short of the amount the company requested.

title: Unusual Calm Hung Over Stock Market, Until Friday
summary: Dow's unchanged close Tuesday had been the most dramatic example in a string of very small closing changes. Until Friday, the stock market had been eerily quiet of late.

title: Trump Makes Second High Court Bid to Block Release of Financial Records
summary: A day after bid to stymie New York City's call for president's tax returns, his lawyers ask for stay of congressional subpoena. WASHINGTON-President Trump on Friday asked the Supreme Court to halt a ruling requiring his longtime accounting firm to turn over volumes of his financial records to congressional investigators.

title: Maersk Will Restrain Costs, Expand Logistics Services on Weak Shipping Outlook
summary: World's largest container line won't buy new ships for now as trade uncertainty, capacity race hit ocean trade. A.P. Moeller-Maersk AS is stepping back from buying new vessels as the Danish shipping giant focuses on controlling costs and targets its growth efforts to inland logistics rather than oceangoing trade.

title: Pennsylvania Man Convicted in Three Deaths
summary: Jury to decide on sentence of death or life in prison. DOYLESTOWN, Pa.-A jury on Friday convicted a man in the slayings of three young men whose bodies were found buried at a suburban Philadelphia farm.

title: Billionaire Mexican Is Behind Company Suing Government
summary: Court action pits Ricardo Salinas Pliego against the government of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, with whom the businessman has allied. MEXICO CITY-A lawsuit concerning a tech startup is pitting Mexican billionaire Ricardo Salinas Pliego, a key private-sector ally of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, against the Mexican leader's government.

title: U.S. Oil Production Bucks Drilling Slowdown, Keeps Crude Prices in Check
summary: Steady climb in U.S. output proves to be an obstacle to OPEC's price-setting agenda. Drillers are laying down rigs, hydraulic-fracturing equipment sits idle and U.S. energy producers are promising fiscal restraint. Yet domestic oil production keeps rising-a riddle that has flummoxed traders and kept oil prices trading in a narrow band in recent weeks.

title: Chileans to Vote on Whether to Scrap Dictatorship-Era Constitution
summary: Government, leading political parties agree to hold referendum in April after nearly a month of unrest. Chile's government and leading political parties agreed to hold a referendum in April on scuttling the country's dictatorship-era constitution to replace it with one that enshrines social rights, a concession to Chileans protesting for broad public benefits.

title: New York Fed Adds $68.343 Billion
summary: Liquidity comes in form of a repurchase agreement operation. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $68.343 billion to financial markets on Friday.

title: Waterproof Jackets That Won't Leave You Feeling Clammy
summary: The latest waterproof materials will keep you comfortable and dry, without that swampy feeling. RAIN JACKETS may keep you dry-it's literally what they're designed to do-but even the best tend to feel crinkly and suffocating, creating a clammy environment beneath your outer layer that practically negates the water-repellent technology you paid extra for.

title: States, District of Columbia Sue EPA Over Emissions Standards
summary: Suit seeks to preserve states' ability to impose emissions rules that surpass federal standards. WASHINGTON-A coalition of 23 states and the District of Columbia sued the Trump administration Friday to preserve the ability of states to set vehicle-emissions rules that surpass federal standards.

title: Former Herbalife Executives Charged With Conspiracy to Bribe Chinese Officials
summary: Chinese nationals Yanliang Li and Hongwei Yang were charged with conspiracy to violate the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Justice Department charged two former executives of Herbalife Nutrition Ltd. with conspiracy to bribe Chinese government officials.

title: France Plans to Host Ukraine Peace Summit to End Conflict
summary: Leaders of France, Russia, Ukraine and Germany to meet in December; new report into 2014 downing of Malaysian passenger jet further implicates Russia. MOSCOW-European leaders will meet with the presidents of Ukraine and Russia next month in an effort to advance rocky negotiations to end the conflict in Ukraine.

title: U.S. Administration Unveils Transparency Rule in Hospital Pricing
summary: Plans to propose similar requirement for insurers; legal challenges are likely. Hospitals and insurers would be forced to disclose their secret negotiated rates for the first time under a far-reaching plan released Friday by the Trump administration.

title: U.S. IT Company Discloses Potential Sanctions Violations
summary: DXC Technology Co. submitted voluntary disclosure to U.S. and U.K. sanctions regulators. U.S. technology services company DXC Technology Co. has notified regulators of potential sanctions violations.

title: Hulu Is Raising the Price of Hulu + Live TV in December
summary: New monthly price tag will be $54.99. Walt Disney Co. -controlled streaming platform Hulu said Friday it is raising the price of its live and on-demand TV offering starting next month.

title: For Wall Street Analysts, It's Location, Location, Location
summary: New research shows that analysts are unduly influenced by what is going on close to home. Groups of people are often better at figuring things out together than alone. But the wisdom of the crowd can get dumbed down when everybody in the crowd has the same perspective.

title: Political Ads Are Flourishing Online. Few Agree How to Regulate Them.
summary: Tech companies and states redraw rules as vacancies and disagreement paralyze FEC. Political campaigns and advocacy groups plan to funnel billions of dollars into digital advertising over the next year. But as federal guidelines on how to regulate these ads are virtually absent, some states are making their own laws, while technology giants are drawing the lines for acceptable political speech on the fly.

title: Fed Flags Elevated Asset Prices, High Debt as U.S. Risks
summary: In third financial-stability report, officials again warn on corporate borrowing. WASHINGTON- The Federal Reserve identified elevated asset prices and historically high debt owed by U.S. businesses as top vulnerabilities facing the U.S. financial system, according to the latest copy of the central bank's financial stability report.

title: The Boardroom Sage Who Was Into Good Governance Before It Was Cool
summary: Ira Millstein has long argued that America's biggest companies have responsibilities to society. Now the rest of the business world is coming around to his view.. Corporate-governance guru Ira Millstein has long argued that companies have larger obligations to society that go beyond profits. Now some of America's most influential CEOs are giving this opinion a fresh look.

title: Twitter to Restrict How Certain Advertisers Target Users
summary: Social-media company no longer allowing groups promoting causes to target users by ZIP Code or possible political affiliation. Twitter Inc. said it would no longer allow certain types of geographic or keyword targeting for advertisers promoting any type of cause, as part of rules aimed at blocking most political-related ads on its platform.

title: Canned Tuna Maker Bumble Bee Preps for Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Bumble Bee's mounting legal expenses from a criminal conviction and class-action litigation have drained its liquidity. Bumble Bee Foods LLC is preparing to file for bankruptcy within days over mounting legal expenses stemming from its involvement in a conspiracy to fix prices on canned tuna, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: In 'Strangelove,' War Is Hell, Funny As Hell
summary: Stanley Kubrick's 'Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb' found humor in the existential terror of conflict..

title: Ill Wind from U.S. Shale Patch Kicks Up Sandstorm
summary: A rush of capital into the industry has created an oversupply of sand used for fracking. A group of companies supplying oil and gas drillers turn out to be built on a foundation of sand.

title: The Epic Afterlife of Troy
summary: For 3,000 years, artists have been inspired by the city and its legends.. Scholars have long debated whether the city of Troy described in Homer's "Iliad" actually existed, but its afterlife is indisputably real. For some 3,000 years, the legend of Troy's destruction by the Greeks has been told and retold. "Troy: Myth and Reality," a new exhibition opening Nov. 21 at London's British Museum, dramatizes that legacy with 294 objects, ranging from ancient papyri to 21st-century installation art. Alexandra Villing, an archaeologist at the museum and one of the exhibition's curators, says that the variety of exhibits included in the show demonstrates that the legend of Troy "is a great story that covers all aspects of human nature."

title: Rolling Stone Ronnie Wood on Painting Time
summary: The Rolling Stone turned artist painted 47 custom watches, each evoking the rock star's life. And of his bandmates amid health struggles: 'We will rock on for longer.'. For Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood, 72, a painting can be just as intense as live music. At a launch for his latest collaboration with the watch brand Bremont, he told WSJ. that seeing a René Magritte show years ago was a life-changing experience. "I said to someone when I left the exhibition, 'I've just seen Magritte live,'" he says. "It was so intense, all the color. It was like being in the presence of a great group and hearing a great piece of music played. It was exhausting."

title: Sen. Warren Created Opening for Bloomberg
summary: Michael Bloomberg thoroughly understands business, Sens. Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders do not.. Regarding your editorial "The Water's Fine, Mr. Bloomberg" (Nov. 9): I am a moderate Democrat and this is your first editorial in some time that I agree with completely. Michael Bloomberg thoroughly understands business, Sens. Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders do not. Sen. Warren wants to break up Amazon and other large tech companies to protect smaller firms. A close reading of the policy proposals on her website indicates to me she thinks the Warren administration could manage competition better than the market itself. I see her, 100 years ago, fighting-one of her favorite words-to protect the horse-and-buggy industry from Ford and GM. Sen. Warren should add an expert who understands economies of scale and scope in high tech to her group of advisers. That is highly unlikely, as I expect that individual would not adhere to Sen. Warren's party line.

title: Income Inequality and Housing Affordability
summary: Michael Carter bemoans housing costs that single teachers can't afford. But this problem began in the late 1970s when banks began considering a wife's income when approving home loans for married couples.. In his Nov. 13 letter, Michael Carter bemoans housing costs that single teachers can't afford in his response to Phil Gramm and John F. Early's "The Truth About Income Inequality" (op-ed, Nov. 4). But this problem began in the late 1970s when banks began considering a wife's income when approving home loans for married couples. Before that time, most banks would only consider a husband's income. This sounds so sexist today because we've forgotten that before effective and widely used birth control, married women were considered poor risks by bankers who needed assurances that women would not leave their jobs.

title: U.K. Labour Party to Nationalize Broadband if It Gains Power
summary: The party would nationalize part of the country's telecom networks, part of its most leftwing platform in decades. LONDON-The U.K.'s main opposition Labour Party, maneuvering for advantage in national elections next month, is planning to run on its most leftwing platform in decades. Its latest plan: nationalize part of the country's telecoms network and give citizens free broadband.

title: Never Forget the Berlin Wall's Evil Purpose
summary: It was a huge visual lesson to me about the horrors of a well-guarded wall that divided an ideology, a culture and families.. Your articles about the Berlin Wall caught my interest ("Thirty Years After the Fall of the Wall," Review, Nov. 9). I was a young woman when I toured Europe via a road trip and visited the Berlin Wall in 1963. We were able to access East Berlin by going through the Brandenburg Gate. The drab appearance of East Berlin was in stark contrast to the vitality and modern structures in West Berlin. It was a huge visual lesson to me about the horrors of a well-guarded wall that divided an ideology, a culture and families. Like others, I rejoiced when the wall was eventually torn down. I didn't know what became of pieces of the wall, but I found a portion of it in rural Hope, Idaho, when I moved to the area in 1993. A German-American industrialist had a large home on the Hope Peninsula. Outside the gates to the property, he had installed a protected segment of the Berlin Wall. It features a four-foot wide section that has colorful cartoon drawings of a duck, similar to the Disney character. The theme seems happy, yet it belies the ugly truth of the origin and purpose of the wall. From time to time, I take visitors to see the remnant of the wall. It is of historical interest, and it is a reminder that we should never take our freedoms for granted.

title: Nobody Is Forced to Sign Car Loans They Can't Afford
summary: Car loans aren't forcing borrowers underwater. Nothing is forcing borrowers underwater.. Consumer bankruptcy law offers a solution to underwater vehicle loans ("Mounting Car Debt Traps More Drivers," Page One, Nov. 11). Chapter 13 bankruptcy law allows for what is known as a vehicle cram. If an individual files for Chapter 13 bankruptcy and has owned the vehicle for over 910 days, the terms of an auto loan can be modified so that the borrower pays back only the market value of the vehicle. The underwater portion of the loan is treated like credit-card debt and discharged (forgiven) in the bankruptcy. In addition, the interest rate on the existing loan can be lowered to prime plus 1% to 2%.

title: Bring Back Thee and Thou? What Dost Thou Think?
summary: Might I suggest that we resurrect "thee" and "thou" as the second person singular pronoun and return "you" to the plural where it belongs.. Regarding "Pronoun Pyrotechnics," Henry Hitchings's review of Allan Metcalf's "The Life of Guy" (Bookshelf, Nov. 5) and complaints about the ascendancy of the expression "you guys": Might I suggest that we resurrect "thee" and "thou" as the second person singular pronoun and return "you" to the plural where it belongs. Not only would this remind English speakers that, like many other languages, we too conjugate our verbs, at least in the singular (e.g., I think, thou thinkest and he or she thinks), but it might make Shakespeare and the Bible marginally easier to read. "What thinkest thou?" Or, given English's peculiar attachment to auxiliary verbs, perhaps I should instead say, "what dost thou think?"

title: How Camera Brands Are Keeping Pace with Smartphones
summary: Evolving smartphone tech is putting camera brands on their heels, forcing them to adopt smarter features that teens, social influencers and new parents crave. SCROLL BACK to the early days of Instagram and you'll find a graveyard of poorly lit selfies and dated duckface snapshots-all a far cry from the elevated social media content savvy creators send out today via their "Pro"-level iPhone 11s. Now, as the online influencer market passes $8 billion annually, popular camera brands are looking for a way back in: Call it the "If you can't beat 'em join 'em" approach.

title: Helena Bonham Carter's Royal Role
summary: She went 'to idiotic lengths' to research Princess Margaret to play her in the new season of Netflix's 'The Crown'. At a party at Windsor Castle in 1997, Helena Bonham Carter spotted Princess Margaret standing alone. She was holding a drink, recalls the English actress, and looking lonely. "It's hard to be a public figure, standing on your own, no one talking to you, without feeling vulnerable," says Ms. Bonham Carter. "So I went up to her." As they talked, the princess told the actress, then 31, "You are getting better at acting."

title: Pope Francis Weighs Adding 'Ecological Sin' to Church Teachings
summary: Pontiff considers introducing an abiding concern-environmental protection-into Catechism. VATICAN CITY-Pope Francis, who has made the environment a signature cause of his pontificate, said he was strongly considering adding the category of "ecological sin" to the Catholic Church's official compendium of teachings.

title: Browns Star Myles Garrett Suspended After Attacking Steelers Quarterback With Helmet
summary: After ugly brawl, defensive lineman is out for a minimum of the rest of this regular season and postseason. Cleveland Browns defensive lineman Myles Garrett has been suspended indefinitely by the NFL after taking Pittsburgh Steelers' quarterback Mason Rudolph's helmet off his head and using it to bludgeon him.

title: Bond Funds Lose Appeal as Yields Rise
summary: Intelsat bonds rebound. A steady rise in Treasury yields has investors putting the brakes on their contributions to U.S. bond funds.

title: Business Wakes Up to the Magic of Sleep
summary: Your company thinks you need to go to bed. Your exhausted columnist has been saying that for years.. All my life, I've been told I'm sleeping too much.

title: She's a Couples Counselor, but for Your Work Relationships
summary: Resume Subscription. Michael Lovitch and Hollis Carter sat side-by-side on a therapist's couch in a Manhattan office tower late one Friday, getting ready for the move that would take Mr. Carter to Utah and make theirs a long-distance relationship.

title: Stock-Market Technical Indicators Flash Warning
summary: The indicators have long been part of the lore of technical trading. Traders were abuzz this week after the "Hindenburg Omen" and "Titanic Syndrome" technical indicators flashed in unison-an unusual event that sometimes precedes a selloff.

title: Federal Prosecutors Probe Giuliani's Links to Ukrainian Energy Projects
summary: Associates told others that Giuliani stood to profit from natural-gas project pitched alongside campaign for investigations of Joe Biden. Federal prosecutors in New York are investigating whether Rudy Giuliani stood to profit personally from a Ukrainian natural-gas business pushed by two associates who also aided his efforts there to launch investigations that could benefit President Trump, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Mediterranean Shipping Co. Shakes Up Senior Management
summary: Founder Gianluigi Aponte to step down as chairman of the world's second-biggest ocean cargo mover. Mediterranean Shipping Co. Chairman Gianluigi Aponte will step down and will be replaced by his son, Diego Aponte, in a shakeup at the top of the world's second-largest container line, people with direct knowledge of the matter said.

title: Hong Kong's Week of Rage Boils Over
summary: Clashes between protesters and police since Monday turned universities into battlefields and gridlocked the city. HONG KONG-Antigovernment protesters and police shocked Hong Kong with some of the ugliest incidents in nearly six months of unrest this week, leaving the city's leaders scrambling for a way to restore order under increasing pressure from Beijing.

title: Slower U.S. Consumer Spending Will Cost the Economy Momentum
summary: Sluggish retail-sales growth indicates consumers can't be the economy's only engine. U.S. consumers are doing fine, but they don't look like the force they were earlier in the year.

title: Brazil Deepens China Ties in About-Face
summary: President Bolsonaro reaches out as domestic economy sputters. BRASÍLIA-As a fiery conservative candidate last year, President Jair Bolsonaro warned that China was a rapacious predator out to exploit Brazil and he pledged loyalty to a leader he called his American idol, Donald Trump.

title: J.C. Penney's Sales Fall, but Outlook Improves
summary: Retailer expects adjusted earnings for the fiscal year to be higher than previously forecast; shares rise. J.C. Penney Co. reported another quarter of falling sales but boosted part of its financial outlook for this fiscal year, sending its battered shares up in Friday trading.

title: The GOP Has Three Defenses of Donald Trump. Only One Really Works.
summary: He did it and shouldn't have. But it should be left to the voters to decide.. There was an oddly incongruous quality to the start of the public impeachment hearings of President Donald Trump this week. The event was treated by the media like a cross between a state funeral and an election night-all pomp and circumstance, hours and hours of live coverage, punctuated by sonorous pronouncements from the high priests of the networks. You know it's a moment of true national gravity when "The View" gets bumped for a congressional committee hearing.

title: The Wines to Buy This Thanksgiving: A Guide to America's Up-and-Coming Regions
summary: From Maryland Syrah to Rocky Mountain Riesling, exciting wines are turning up in unexpected places thanks to intrepid American producers. Raise a toast to our nation's bounty with these off-the-beaten-track bottles. THE FAMED frontier spirit of the men and women who helped settle the country we now call the United States required courage and conviction and the willingness to leave the familiar behind for worlds unknown-possible riches or possible ruin. It's the same spirit that drives so many American winemakers today, men and women who often risk all in the hope of producing a world-class wine.

title: New Jersey Demands Uber Fork Over Nearly $650 Million in Unpaid Taxes, Fines
summary: Ride-sharing firm is struggling to prevent its drivers from being classified as employees. Uber Technologies Inc. has been hit with an almost $650 million bill in unpaid employment taxes and fines from New Jersey, marking another setback for the ride-sharing firm as it struggles to prevent its drivers from being classified as employees.

title: Swedish TV Contacts SEB Over Money Laundering
summary: The Swedish lender says it analyzes its business in the Baltics and elsewhere to assess the risks of being used for criminal activity. STOCKHOLM- Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken AB said it has been contacted by a Swedish TV show that claims it has information on the bank ahead of a program it will air on suspected money laundering in the Baltics.

title: Lawmakers Ask Watchdog to Probe Case of FBI Source Found Dead Overseas
summary: Letter seeks information on William Paul Reilly's work and expresses concern about officials' 'lack of candor'. Lawmakers have requested that the Justice Department's independent watchdog investigate the case of William Paul Reilly, a Federal Bureau of Investigation counterterrorism source who went missing in Russia in 2015 and whose remains were discovered in a separatist territory of eastern Ukraine more than three years later.

title: Do You Love Trains? Well, You Can Buy One
summary: Resume Subscription. A few years back, Robin Douglas was on choir practice break at his suburban Los Angeles church when a fellow parishioner came over with a startling pronouncement.

title: 'The Second Sleep' Review: The Once and Future West
summary: In Robert Harris's new novel, a great disaster has pushed civilization back to an epoch of homespun cloth, packhorse transport and theocratic law.. 'Knowledge alters everything," thinks a priest in the England of 1468 when he begins to stumble across dangerous learning that the Church abhors. By this point, readers of "The Second Sleep," the 13th novel by English journalist-turned-writer Robert Harris, have the knowledge that they need to grasp his book's backstory. Reviewers should always beware of spoilers, but in this case the sharing of secrets seems justified. For this year belongs, as we rapidly learn, not to the medieval past but the far future. Western societies have reverted to the horse-drawn, timber-built and torch-lit existence of their ancestors. And they have reset time: The "Year of Our Risen Lord 1468" lies eight centuries ahead of us. Fragments of our own world do survive, but only as shattered pieces of a mysterious lost civilization. One baffling pocket-size relic made of plastic and glass carries on its back "the ultimate symbol of the ancients' hubris and blasphemy-an apple with a bite taken out of it."

title: Trump to Attend NATO Summit in London
summary: White House lauds alliance, in shift after president pushed members to increase military spending. WASHINGTON-President Trump, whose persistent criticism of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has caused friction within the 29-member alliance, will attend the group's summit in London early next month.

title: In Sri Lankan Vote, Tamils Seek Defeat of War's Victor
summary: Disappearance of insurgents who surrendered a decade ago weighs on Saturday's presidential election. KILINOCHCHI, Sri Lanka-For the mothers of Tamil insurgents who disappeared after surrendering to Sri Lanka's military at the end of the country's 30-year war, the 1,000th day of their continuous roadside protest falls on Saturday-election day.

title: What It's Like to Retire Abroad
summary: We talked to the expats who had previously written for us about retiring outside the U.S. Do they still like it? Have any returned home?. So...how did your decision to retire overseas turn out?

title: Innovation Should Be Made in the U.S.A.
summary: Offshoring by American companies has destroyed our manufacturing base and our capacity to develop new products and processes. It's time for a national industrial policy.. In 1987, as the Reagan administration was nearing its end, the economists Stephen S. Cohen and John Zysman issued a prophetic warning: "If high-tech is to sustain a scale of activity sufficient to matter to the prosperity of our economy...America must control the production of those high-tech products it invents and designs." Production, they continued, is "where the lion's share of the value added is realized."

title: The 11-Year-Old Dissident: Hong Kong's Schoolchildren Fuel Protests
summary: Resume Subscription. HONG KONG-Before the 8 a.m. bell rings at high schools across the city, uniformed students at some of them gather to join hands, chanting protest slogans or singing "the revolution of our times," words from a popular protest anthem.

title: Brazil Dam Collapse Prompts Potential Rule Shakeup for Miners
summary: Proposal by industry group calls for strict standards on how companies build and operate mine-waste dams in wake of deadly Brumadinho accident. A group representing the world's largest miners published draft proposals for strict new standards to govern how companies build and operate the sort of mine-waste dam that collapsed in Brazil early this year, killing 270 people.

title: A Social Revolution in Saudi Arabia
summary: Under its controversial crown prince, the kingdom is allowing more personal freedom, from cafes to concerts, even while cracking down on political dissent. The mosh pit was packed on a recent night in the Saudi capital of Riyadh. As the Jamaican rapper Sean Paul performed, young men and women raised their iPhones, swayed along and mouthed the lyrics: "I'm in love with your body...and now my bed sheets smell like you."

title: Move Over Viagra Ads, Here Come the Financial Advisers
summary: The SEC could soon let investment advisors hire celebrity endorsers. What could possibly go wrong?. An ad pops up on your phone. There's your favorite NBA superstar at the foul line. Positioning himself for a free throw, he looks into the camera: "I've known Caesar Cash for years. He's a straight shooter, just like me." He fires the ball at the hoop. Swish! "Cash Financial Advisors," grins the star. "Move your money to the straight shooters."

title: Five Best: J.D. Dickey on Books About American Preachers
summary: The author, most recently, of 'American Demagogue: The Great Awakening and the Rise and Fall of Populism'. By Harry S. Stout (1991)

summary: Two dead in Southern California school shooting, U.S. House holds impeachment hearings, Venice submerged by near-record flooding and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Political Books: Making Evangelicalism Great Again
summary: The desire of many white evangelicals to gain political influence is at the root of their identity crisis today.. "Donald Trump is no devout Christian," Angela Denker writes in "Red State Christians: Understanding the Voters Who Elected Donald Trump" (Fortress, 309 pages, $26.99). As the Republican front-runner in 2016, she tells us, Mr. Trump "failed the Bible test when asked his favorite passage: 'Two Corinthians?' he ventured, failing to realize that the biblical book is referred to as Second Corinthians." His critics ridiculed Mr. Trump for the line, evidently not realizing that numbered biblical books are commonly called "one," "two" and "three" in Britain-"Two Samuel," "Three John" and so on. Even supposing Mr. Trump didn't pick up the habit from his Scottish mother, his cultured despisers revealed their own parochialism. Ms. Denker manages to compound the error-the "Two Corinthians" line came in a speech at Liberty University, not in answer to a question about his favorite biblical book.

title: 'Retreat From Moscow' Review: Repelling the Winter Invaders
summary: Soldiers and civilians on the Eastern front in 1941 were caught up in the Nazi 'war of annihilation.' Some German soldiers watched as their train of vitally needed supplies was blown up by their own forces to prevent it from falling into the Soviet hands.. It is a commonplace that the winter of 1941-42 marked a turning point in the course of World War II. Everybody knows, or thinks he knows, that after a German invasion that almost reached Moscow, the Red Army abandoned its defensive strategy and went over to the counterattack in early December 1941-and that this change of strategy sealed the fate of Nazi Germany even before the Americans entered the war a week later. It is also widely believed that Hitler, whatever his other mistakes, saved the Wehrmacht from a Napoleonic-style rout by insisting that it stand fast rather than fall back.

title: Fiction: Bad News Served With the Morning Tea
summary: In the stories of Elizabeth Bowen, passions, hatreds and heartbreaks are hidden amid the prosaic effects of the drawing room and the boudoir.. In Elizabeth Bowen's 1926 short story "The Visitor," a boy emerges from the spare bedroom in the house of family friends to discover the pleasures of a perfectly appointed breakfast table. "No sun could have been rounder or more luminous than the brass kettle genially ridiculous upon a tripod, a blue flame trembling beneath it. There were dahlias, pink and crimson, and marmalade in a glass pot shaped like a barrel cast a shadow of gold on the tablecloth. There was a monstrous tea-cosy, its frill peaked intelligently . . . There were parrots printed on the cosy-they battled with one another-so brilliant one could almost hear them screech," Bowen continues, describing the scene with the disarming generosity of the breakfast spread, until the sudden swerve that throws it all into disarray: "Could a world hold death that held that cosy?"

title: Children's Books: Page Turners for Early Learners
summary: The not-so-simple art of the board book for infants and toddlers.. Board books appear in all respects to be simply . . . books. They have pages and spines and covers; they contain pictures and words. Here's the thing, though: A board book is not so much a book in the conventional sense as a mechanism for sparking the parent-child interactions that are so valuable for the growing brain. The best board books engage babies and toddlers in thinking, seeing and pointing, while also eliciting adult commentary and questioning, all of which promotes emotional and cognitive flourishing.

title: 'Metropolitan Stories' Review: Pictures From an Institution
summary: A collection of stories set at the monumental institution where the author worked for more than 25 years.. A life-size marble statue of Adam, a major artwork from Renaissance Venice, is tired of maintaining his pose on a pedestal, apple in hand, at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art. The serene, idealized figure, sculpted by Tullio Lombardo in the early 1490s, yearns above all to move, and eventually he succumbs to the temptation. After centuries of constraint he stretches his body like a passenger after a cramped overnight flight, and topples off the pedestal. A security guard finds him smashed into little pieces on the floor. It will take the restorers 11 years to rebuild him.

title: Mysteries: Counting Down the Last Three Dozen
summary: New novels from Steven Pressfield, Martin Cruz Smith and Martha Grimes take readers to Israel, Siberia and Cornwall.. The year is 2034 in Steven Pressfield's dystopian thriller "36 Righteous Men" (Norton, 341 pages, $26.95), and the world is taking a beating from climate change. Devastating super-storms are common, nighttime temperatures are in triple digits, and experts are predicting "the end of human life on Earth within a generation." Meanwhile, crime marches on.

title: Leaders of Neighboring Countries Share a Name. Confusion Ensues.
summary: Romania's new prime minister, Ludovic Orban, has the same last name as his counterpart in Hungary; 'I'm the good one'. People have long mixed up Bucharest, Romania's capital city, with Budapest, in neighboring Hungary, some 400 miles northwest.

summary: American head of Nissan's studio in San Diego encouraged workers to clash-or play beach volleyball. Jerry Hirshberg's rock 'n' roll career was brief. summary: The bank also said it would invest €1.5 billion in renewable energy and energy efficiency projects. The European Investment Bank said late Thursday that it would end financing for fossil-fuel energy projects from the end of 2021 onward, marking the latest blow to oil-and-gas companies as the European Union readies for its version of the Green New Deal.

title: Warren Tax Plan Would Bring Rates Over 100% for Some
summary: Presidential hopeful proposes wealth tax and levy on unrealized gains, a combination that could alter investing. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren has unveiled sweeping tax proposals that would push federal tax rates on some billionaires and multimillionaires above 100%.

title: Venice's Rising Tides Leave Businesses Struggling to Stay Afloat
summary: The city has faced the second-worst inundation since records began. VENICE, Italy-When huge floods swept through Venice earlier this week, Matteo Wahba watched in horror as the waters inundated his restaurant. The acqua alta, the second-worst experienced by the majestic city in 150 years of records, ruined six of his fridges, two dishwashers, a pasta cooker and an ice machine.

title: Tariffs Aren't the Only Driver of Auto Stocks
summary: Hopes that the trade war is easing have buoyed the European auto sector in recent weeks, but another profit warning from Daimler is a reality check. Trade-deal hopes have given investors a useful opportunity to bail out of European auto stocks. Daimler's latest profit warning shows why they should seize it.

summary: Due to late entry into the presidential race, many potential donors and advisers have already committed to other candidates. WASHINGTON-Former Massachusetts Gov. summary: Recent fast-food breakthroughs like Popeyes chicken sandwich and Impossible Whoppers represent small victories in what has become a tough market. Making a chicken sandwich isn't hard, but just try making one fly.

title: One Problem With Flu Shot? Not Enough People Get It
summary: Fewer than 50% get vaccinated annually, putting old and young at risk. Each year, influenza sickens millions of people. But typically, too few Americans get the flu shot to shield everyone from the contagious disease.

title: Patrick's Ties to Health-Care Industry Could be Liability
summary: Other Democratic presidential candidates are likely to attack newcomer to field; the Pentagon embeds fewer journalists with troops in Afghanistan. DEVAL PATRICK'S TIES to health-care and drug companies could make him a punching bag for Democratic candidates who support single-payer health care and criticize the pharmaceutical industry. Since leaving the governorship of Massachusetts in 2015, Patrick has served on the boards of American Well Corp., a telemedicine company, and Global Blood Therapeutics , a pharmaceutical firm. Patrick plans to leave both boards.

summary: U.S. cites unfair economic burden posed on American workers and businesses. WASHINGTON-The U.S. has officially started the process of exiting the Paris climate agreement, citing an unfair economic burden posed on American workers and businesses, the State Department said.
